9344FB6B428C4BB9AA81194A5F6D4160.description: Create a pictograph from a concrete graph.

1AA05308EACF464787A0B817895B4B17.description: Collaborate to construct a concrete graph using data collected in the learning environment.

17D3DE24A0F0444DAE64015BD3357120.description: Gather data by sharing answers to questions.

E1643A97265C4DDCB8AF8F010D5227E1.description: Share wonderings about people, things, events, or experiences.

7BDF34D59F7F42CE9256F5796274AA65.description: Data can be represented in a graph.

AABA3C965735438E81878834DFFF1CD1.description: Data can be answers to questions.

BEDA8141E1184706B0572C4F0EA89F96.description: A graph can represent data by using objects, pictures, or numbers.

662771F3046F4FBBA1D1A25F7FF1631E.description: A graph is a visual representation of data.

3561588D5132483CA6A36B2C8F3AF7EB.description: Statistics: The science of collecting, analyzing, visualizing, and interpreting data can inform understanding and decision making.

D29B4D8BD514441DA6BFAFFD65F71B58.description: Relate cycles of seasons to First Nations, Metis, or Inuit practices.

22B3BF8D3E194207A07348FD39292C3C.description: Describe observable changes that indicate a cycle of time.

E02C2B1F592F4BB89AD08C6A0C0229BB.description: Describe cycles of time encountered in daily routines and nature.

D1E360377CCD435FAF0A3E538BF898B4.description: Time can be perceived as a cycle.

615DD870EEA74223A0ACF8D116486C30.description: Time is an experience of change.

2C0D28790DFE430B9FDCCDF07717FE43.description: Cycles from a calendar include days of the week and months of the year.

CFAE0F9DE2BC429A862D2AD6F058AA35.description: First Nations, Metis, and Inuit experience time through sequences and cycles in nature, including cycles of seasons.

AC3686B7D1A44E62BAFE5B65DF9BE679.description: Time can be perceived through observable change.

CD31461052E7402D86B59E2ADA63B969.description: Students explain time in relation to cycles.

2F58D97A918F4B31A88F40CFEDB8AF96.description: Time: Duration is described and quantified by time.

CCC3AF1A70CA4FCF92F4863D07D372F1.description: Extend a sequence of elements in various ways to create repeating patterns.

AC7ACAF5414047A69AB93FB2CB15E168.description: Create different representations of the same repeating pattern or cycle, limited to a pattern core of up to four elements.

5661CA1C6C814910A35D17661A9EA94A.description: Describe change and constancy in repeating patterns and cycles.

6DC7F326510743D59CA7FD643F142D12.description: Identify a missing element in a repeating pattern or cycle.

D6D8B8974D1B4683B185D2B547219584.description: Identify the pattern core, up to four elements, in a cycle.

26147F3C27B848998750BC022764CFD8.description: Investigate cycles found in nature that inform First Nations, Metis, or Inuit practices.

4589DFA1F0FE42AA92916D7AC7F720BD.description: Recognize cycles encountered in daily routines and nature.

2188E866552E424D9525C3CA93C5928E.description: A cycle is a repeating pattern that repeats in the same way forever.

BD0DA52F5A634B959FD70C24DE66C60B.description: A pattern that appears to repeat may not repeat in the same way forever.

A1A4C51D1B0A4FA687E8AB8523CEE0D2.description: A pattern core is a sequence of one or more elements that repeats as a unit.

AF739C320A4F41D4B81BCD82E4FF5CC1.description: The same pattern can be represented with different elements.

F627678AFCCE46979B84859082B91CA0.description: Cycles include seasons, day/night, life cycles and calendars.

04F3CB2E73CD43239BC268A4A4D0F385.description: A cycle can express repetition of events or experiences.

5C3E29D8550F4DFFBEF548C316C4FE84.description: Patterns: Awareness of patterns supports problem solving in various situations.

8510C362D8BA491CBFC898AF0B3CC84D.description: Order objects according to length, area, or capacity.

804C97D5E725400AA8E2698AFDC5E1AD.description: Compare the length, area, or capacity of two objects directly or indirectly using a third object.

FF0C21013FC34A4FA1809742586F4C5C.description: Compare and order objects according to length.

5784ECEE10264C40A50078DA276DB8AF.description: Recognize the height, width, or depth of an object as lengths in various orientations.

CCA3BEBF23414E3E959549BD91568483.description: The size of two objects can be compared indirectly with a third object.

00988E81C4864A3197D083A43B4E70BC.description: Length remains the same if an object is repositioned but may be named differently.

369A5D2057214E5F9B60884E2A0B025B.description: Length is a measurable attribute that describes the amount of fixed space between the end points of an object.

FD2CF08D5475473B89BDD7F4FAC2F403.description: Comparisons of size can be described by using words such as higher, wider and deeper.

2DD0F51DC5C0474485DD9403A939B2D1.description: Indirect comparison is useful when objects are fixed in place or difficult to move.

97F37DC99CEA4CD2B64C9ACC29196FE2.description: Familiar contexts of distance include distance between objects or people, distance between objects on the land, distance between home and school and distance between towns or cities.

E6CCB42B8D5C4D739B8DE2AE5274F7ED.description: The length between any two points in space is called distance.

BDCD7212E73B4C32A9DEAF3C54C76DA1.description: A length does not need to be a straight line.

5AC244F381DF400EAD16311957B0C448.description: Size may refer to the length of an object, including height, width and depth.

49A316F204104D1F889A06568CE65E40.description: Students relate length to the understanding of size.

B6FE9627DE5A404A8FF822DC5B09D5E7.description: Measurement: Attributes such as length, area, volume, and angle are quantified by measurement.

A2E2A12217A9468988D2CF0646917BF3.description: Investigate symmetry of two-dimensional shapes by folding and matching.

434762AEEE0E4B68BAEBC3CF60E20FFC.description: Identify familiar shapes within two- or three-dimensional composite shapes.

A4177A903617403588A5E5CAF5A7E495.description: Compose and decompose two- or three-dimensional composite shapes.

76D192E33D9D4346998CEAC736457335.description: Sort shapes according to one attribute and describe the sorting rule.

162A417E97424C68981D7F68BA6633B5.description: Identify familiar shapes in various sizes and orientations.

D38300DC5563417280D7398AF51E88F5.description: A shape is symmetrical if it can be decomposed into matching halves.

BCED66CEB50E4E6F8C7D44D3711583D8.description: A shape can be modelled in various sizes and orientations.

DF3E67FDC4CC4C71AB95E77870AF483A.description: A line of symmetry indicates the division between the matching halves of a symmetrical shape.

EEA522AC5085460DA88420B90D7427F8.description: A composite shape is composed of two or more shapes.

34CD11D6E3414656960492E84D09E7AA.description: Familiar three-dimensional shapes include cubes, prisms, cylinders, spheres, pyramids and cones.

FE53DB5DAFC0450BBEDD1E83C0F37890.description: Familiar two-dimensional shapes include squares, circles, rectangles and triangles.

4713EF5BAAD14730BE225D89353BF13E.description: Students interpret shape in two and three dimensions.

635AA5D9CE4E4626B86C7A0ADFAD7193.description: Geometry: Shapes are defined and related by geometric attributes.

9682EE58CD854C56B0A3183ED56E1AAC.description: Verify that the two halves of one whole group, shape, or object are the same size.

651EB86EDEB84AD5B348FF2A4A8CE55F.description: Describe one of two equal groups or pieces as one-half.

4A8518B6BD1144699AB5882E11EA27EA.description: Partition a shape or object into two equal pieces.

D87E75EB01F04C1084F3E0B914A21A4A.description: Partition an even set of objects into two equal groups, limited to sets of 10 or less.

C21FF1BBC57B41CDAE593C831D17BB08.description: In a shape or object partitioned into two identical pieces, each piece represents one-half of the whole.

CBFEFF5DE3C44B5EB8B5EFAEAC22612E.description: In a quantity partitioned into two equal groups, each group represents one-half of the whole quantity.

F705B340EAB44397A9C10ACB3121B01E.description: One-half can be one of two equal groups or one of two equal pieces.

5907574F340C499AB7F4CCA74189F25B.description: Students examine one-half as a part-whole relationship.

09C41997218B42A6AAE7B55A9573C855.description: Recall addition number facts, with addends to 10, and related subtraction number facts.

D11929B07E8E4A1B80D82DA5A4B29064.description: Recognize families of related addition and subtraction number facts.

07C4DB6C7E3F428EB3A6B42AB341884C.description: Identify patterns in addition and subtraction, including patterns in addition tables.

74A1BB688C2B4452A57CA3B851C3E6C0.description: Solve problems using addition and subtraction.

8BE639F4365442E182ABB1E020C808A1.description: Determine a missing quantity in a sum or difference, within 20, in a variety of ways.

AD6086B611BD47478E10476AAD2D4348.description: Check differences and sums using inverse operations.

D40384C168A24C1488E48C098753AAEC.description: Relate addition and subtraction to various contexts involving composition or decomposition of quantity.

CC06B6AF716248ECAB85D7C120CF3D83.description: Model addition and subtraction within 20 in various ways, including with a balance.

203C1472710D47829E4976DD1A62622E.description: Visualize quantities between 10 and 20 as compositions of 10 and another quantity.

4B5A2695F65D4C1684261582968117EB.description: Addition number facts have related subtraction number facts.

12ADA20117284FA8803165A14F107E8C.description: Addition and subtraction are opposite (inverse) mathematical operations.

628C6C2A24FB4BD192C74943DDC00FFB.description: Addition and subtraction are processes that describe the composition and decomposition of quantity.

E244209C02E54105BBCD436068EBBA1D.description: Fact families are groups of related addition and subtraction number facts.

A0AB156ECDEB4A9E9B9EEE4FF31A1839.description: Addition and subtraction number facts represent part-part-whole relationships.

A2BCFC4583DB43F4BC05AF2BFC4C10E8.description: A missing quantity in a sum or difference can be represented in different ways, including a+b=?, a+?=c, e?f=?, e??=g, ??f=g

CB86D2F4F9064BE08C207E1F1A16DCFC.description: Addition of 0 to any number, or subtraction of 0 from any number, results in the same number (zero property).

88F08E10610040CDA546049A6CFC2CA8.description: The order in which two quantities are subtracted affects the difference.

10C4ACCEB9A4472BB5B15F908BFA60D5.description: The order in which two quantities are added does not affect the sum (commutative property).

7B1C6A801A8945348C5B8B7119CEB8AA.description: Sums and differences can be expressed symbolically using the addition sign, +, the subtraction sign, -, and the equal sign, =.

59EE551A3A8549ECB03BF66AD70DA956.description: Addition and subtraction strategies include counting on counting back, decomposition, compensation and making tens.

A8A5C95ED52845DCB2E04F9CC35872B8.description: Strategies are meaningful steps taken to solve problems.

9F4D529842B24AFFAD6E92A30D249D4A.description: Addition and subtraction can be modelled using a balance.

3970D816CFB4425CB856874C31C9BE91.description: Subtraction can be applied in various contexts, including comparing two quantities, taking away one quantity from another and finding a part of a whole.

ED65076158B64781AB42F0849EC45F20.description: Addition can be applied in various contexts, includingcombining parts to find the whole and increasing an existing quantity.

50870F9A67A541A7B631A4A88405074C.description: Quantities can be composed or decomposed to model a change in quantity.

8F103F4F7E194B9FA4CBC6BF7A242223.description: Students examine addition and subtraction within 20.

91698420E0044108ABD62260461759AE.description: Identify a quantity of 0 in familiar situations

B9010719C1004AE4B10C12B31F1443CE.description: Represent quantities using words, numerals, objects, or pictures

4619480DDACE41E09C74BE666FEEF17E.description: Represent a quantity relative to another, including symbolically.

761D4296B93643CCBDFB80CBCC749AFE.description: Identify numbers that are one more, two more, one less, and two less than a given number.

861D226B816542C7B59ECE5B37A2EC47.description: Investigate equal and unequal quantities, including using a balance model.

1AADF0F1A46C48858D679E5D74EE801B.description: Demonstrate conservation of number when sharing or grouping.

0FAE41F689344E7F880D3DE049F50936.description: Partition a set of objects by sharing and grouping.

267A89D0D7234B0A81CC1C3F96DFE19F.description: Skip count to 20, forward by 2s, starting at 0.

A777C65B4E924FCABD35EEF6ADBBD187.description: Skip count to 100, forward by 5s and 10s, starting at 0.

7F902C28B25D49938453F254E070F2B4.description: Count within 100, forward by 1s, starting at any number, according to the counting principles.

1D8E65AA371846B8BFCA9D95F8F53070.description: Equality is a balance between two quantities.

F63C4D95AFD64038BAA4CC2FDC59D507.description: Two quantities are equal when there is the same number of objects in both sets.

439CFA8F035B486EAF69AAA374808ED4.description: A quantity can be perceived as the composition of smaller quantities.

3FC844EAD7D649A7986B6C7EC0D70C68.description: Quantity can be partitioned by sharing or grouping.

34FC93D4E1FA4279B3C12E9325C1BD26.description: A quantity can be determined by counting more than one object in a set at a time.

2EE5413C860646FFB1DFB0F4A2E57A9F.description: Each number counted includes all previous numbers (counting principle: hierarchical inclusion).

5FF6AC1A421247778B3E63A42CDE3C03.description: Quantity in the world is represented in multiple ways.

0DA40D895E554FFB94F89900CEC449D3.description: Quantity is expressed in words and numerals based on patterns.

9AF1BF98528340419937EE5861BF8EF3.description: The unequal sign, \not = , is used to show that two quantities are not equal.

9FA1A6563898450E9EB1F62F4778358B.description: The equal sign, = , is used to show equality between two quantities.

C168768DCE1C44C1939181F30CE346C3.description: Equality can be modelled using a balance.

B615961EAF6443F0B88DA077BDE0BEDC.description: Comparisons of quantity can be described by using words such as equal, not equal, less and more.

D0A7F335A8CB45BBA2B14CD7119B51B3.description: Familiar arrangements of small quantities facilitate subitizing.

D7DACACEAECB4C1EBCDB5554427F8BBF.description: Grouping involves partitioning a quantity into groups of a certain size.

0D536BF0B4474775B4B0FD7909E6F395.description: Sharing involves partitioning a quantity into a certain number of groups.

D5B6E0AEFA204CD78D851E2EA3BDBA4B.description: Counting more than one object at a time is called skip counting.

3E8D43C7082E491BBF9B9E2BF92354C3.description: Counting can begin at any number.

050F58D21CB449A4A7E3AF92325CDDA2.description: The absence of quantity is represented by 0.

3C622EF7169F4C4D8B660ED15A9BA619.description: A numeral is a symbol or group of symbols used to represent a number.

81D26D2E6E88467788117C779F45AD18.description: Students interpret and explain quantity to 100.

6FD91631C8964554B5BF2B085C708C09.description: Number: Quantity is measured with numbers that enable counting, labelling, comparing, and operating.
